channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
item.description: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: These Trump-Backed Candidates Won’t Promise to Accept Election Results
item.description: Six Republican nominees for governor and the Senate in key midterm states, all backed by Donald Trump, would not commit to accepting the November outcome. Five others did not answer the question.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ballots being counted during this year’s primary in Michigan, where Tudor Dixon, the Republican nominee for governor, declined to commit to accepting the outcome of the November election.

item.title: ‘A Crisis Coming’: The Twin Threats to American Democracy
item.description: The United States faces two distinct challenges, the movement by Republicans who refuse to accept defeat in an election and a growing disconnect between political power and public opinion.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Biden Warns Russia Against Using Unconventional Weapons
item.description: Some officials worry that the more cornered Vladimir Putin feels, particularly with recent setbacks from Ukraine’s counteroffensive, the greater the chance that he might turn to an unconventional weapon.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency services workers collecting unexploded ordnance from the side of the road near Izium on Saturday.

item.title: Trump’s Former Accounting Firm Turns Over Documents to Congress
item.description: Mazars USA delivered an initial set of documents related to the former president’s finances to the House Oversight Committee as part of a settlement.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Documents the accounting firm Mazars USA is providing Congress concern former President Donald J. Trump’s financial dealings from 2014 to 2018.

item.title: How LinkedIn Became a Place to Overshare
item.description: “This isn’t Facebook,” users complain. But others are finding it a valuable place to talk about much more than work.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Neil Webb

item.title: A Welsh Village Embraces Its Bond With the Queen
item.description: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Mary Turner
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moy Road in Aberfan, the site of a school and several houses that were destroyed during an avalanche that killed 116 children and 28 adults in a disaster in October 1966.

item.title: Majority of Latino Voters Out of G.O.P.’s Reach, New Poll Shows
item.description: A New York Times/Siena College poll found Democrats faring far worse than they have in the past with Hispanic voters. But overall, the party has maintained a hold on the Latino electorate.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina, Jazmine Ulloa and Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: New Boosters Test Covid-Weary Nation. Shots Are Here. Do Americans Care?
item.description: The new vaccine campaign is one of the country’s last remaining strategies, as masks have fallen away and quarantines have diminished. So far, the rollout is methodical but muted.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Sharon Otterman and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holly Fulmer administering a new Covid booster to Ethel Brown in the Bronx.

item.title: In NYC, Some Doors Now Close at 10 p.m.
item.description: Is New York still a 24-hour town?
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times

item.title: Is Cold, Blustery Lake Superior a Perfect Cruise Destination?
item.description: As cruising picks up, one small Wisconsin port weighs the pros and cons of more ships and their impact on the town and the environment.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Pearson
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists enjoy the town of Bayfield, Wis., which is attracting passengers from the Viking Octantis, the largest cruise ship that the town of 466 year-round residents has ever seen.

item.title: Invent! Invent! Repeat.
item.description: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro; Photograph by EyeEm/Getty Images

item.title: ‘Are You American?’: The Question I Couldn’t Answer
item.description: An illustrated tale of immigration and belonging.
item.dc:creator: Rumi Hara

item.title: Math Is the Great Secret
item.description: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson
item.media:credit: María Medem

item.title: Why Queen Elizabeth’s Strength Is Putin’s Weakness
item.description: Why the mystical quality we call legitimacy is key for rulers.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: When Diversity Isn’t the Right Kind of Diversity
item.description: No member of Liz Truss’s cabinet is a white man. Why isn’t that considered progress?
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Suella Braverman, Britain’s new home secretary, at 10 Downing Street.

item.title: Sally Schmitt’s French Laundry
item.description: Sally Schmitt sold the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Proudfoot

item.title: How Low Can Republicans Go?
item.description: G.O.P. grapes of wrath at Martha’s Vineyard.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Ray Ewing/Vineyard Gazette, via Reuters
item.media:description: A young man who was part of a group of migrants flown to Martha's Vineyard at the Florida governor’s direction.

item.title: Humans Have a Long History of Making ‘Very Bad Decisions’ to Save Animals
item.description: As scientists push the frontiers of conservation technology, some of their initiatives raise ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: Tim McDonnell
item.media:credit: Javier Jaén

item.title: Why Things May Really Be Different for This Midterm Election
item.description: This cycle, the arguments for Democratic strength cut against the conventional wisdom that the party in power struggles in midterms.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Andrew Sean Greer on Writing ‘Less’
item.description: The novelist discusses his Pulitzer-winning comedy about the travels and travails of a heartbroken writer, and William Finnegan talks about surfing.

item.title: NYC Pizza Guide: the Best Clam Pie, Brooklyn Openings and More
item.description: The most important pizza goings-on across New York City.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: What Did You Wear to That Wedding?
item.description: Were you invited to a wedding with a nontraditional dress code (think: desert chic or coastal glam)? We want to see what you wore.
item.dc:creator: Emma Grillo
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

item.title: Are Geotubes the Answer to Nantucket’s Climate Change Threat?
item.description: In an increasingly litigious conflict, the island’s residents are clashing over how to deal with the effects of climate change: Push back or accept what’s coming?
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Vanessa Leroy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sconset Bluff’s adorable shingled houses continue to attract buyers, although the bluff has been eroding at a rate of three or four feet a year for the last couple of decades.

item.title: Will Smith’s ‘Emancipation’: What Will Apple Do?
item.description: The Civil War drama “Emancipation” finished filming early this year. Now, Apple faces a quandary on what to do with the movie.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Will Smith was barred from the Academy Awards ceremony for the next decade after slapping Chris Rock onstage at this year’s awards.

item.title: In South Korea, President Yoon Treads Fine Line Between U.S. and China
item.description: Yoon Suk-yeol has aligned his country more closely with the United States, but there are limits to how far he can go without angering China or provoking North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk-yeol of South Korea

item.title: Abortion Helps Realign Puerto Rico’s Politics
item.description: Long-dominant political parties are losing power to new ones, including one trying to limit abortion in one of the few U.S. jurisdictions where it remains unrestricted.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A panel of doctors and health experts defending abortion rights at a hearing this month on the island.

item.title: How to Prepare for Flu Season
item.description: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: How to Nurse a Vulnerability Hangover
item.description: That thing you shared last night? It’s probably just fine.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Ard Su

item.title: What Parents Should Know About Enterovirus: Symptoms and Risks
item.description: The C.D.C. has issued an alert about enterovirus D68, which has been linked to rare, polio-like paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who experience paralysis after contracting enterovirus, like this 4-year-old boy, may need physical therapy to help rebuild strength and balance.

item.title: How Family and Friends Helped Get Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: As Covid raged, many Americans hunkered down with family members and relied on friends — and some came away with deepened relationships. Here are a few of their stories.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rita and Jon Ellis at Lermond Pond in Maine. Mr. Ellis credits his wife for his recovery from pancreatic cancer. They are two of the many people who leaned on family and friends to help them through a difficult couple of years.

item.title: Are monkeypox scars permanent?
item.description: The best time to care for skin lesions is in their active phase.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Ernesto Benavides/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: A California Home That Conjures ‘Little Women’ on Acid
item.description: In response to her client’s request, the designer Chloe Warner delivered a layered riot of colors, patterns and styles.
item.dc:creator: Aileen Kwun
item.media:credit: Photo by Laure Joliet. Styled by Yedda Morrison
item.media:description: A view of the dining room of a Piedmont, Calif., home with interiors by Chloe Warner of Redmond Aldrich. The table is a Tulip by Eero Saarinen.
